p: Alpha Glucosidase Inhibitors (AGIs) acarbose, voglibose, and miglitol are effective oral antidiabetic drugs [ 1]. They function by inhibiting the digestive α-glucosidase and α-amylase enzymes that break down starch and other oligosaccharides. [ 1] They have a better safety profile compared to other drugs such as insulin, sulphonylureas, biguanides, meglitinides, thiazolidinediones, and SGLT-2 inhibitors [ 2, 3]. However, they are often accompanied by severe gastrointestinal side effects such as flatulence, diarrhea, and bloating, which limit patient acceptance and compliance [ 4]. The side effects are caused by the fermentation of undigested carbohydrates in the large intestine due to excessive AGIs inhibition of α-amylase [ 5]. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop effective AGIs but without these side effects. Such AGIs should have high selectivity causing high inhibition of α-glucosidase and low inhibition of α-amylase.
